item.title: ClipSketch AI: Turn Video Moments into Hand-Drawn Stories with Google Gemini
item.content:encoded:
Introduction: From Video Frames to Hand-Drawn Stories

Section titled “Introduction: From Video Frames to Hand-Drawn Stories”

Content creators on platforms like Bilibili and Xiaohongshu (Little Red Book) face a common challenge: how to transform video highlights into engaging, shareable content that stands out. Traditional video editing is time-consuming, and converting video moments into stylized content typically requires artistic skills or expensive tools.

ClipSketch AI by RanFeng offers an innovative solution. This open-source web application leverages Google Gemini’s multimodal AI to automatically convert video moments into beautiful hand-drawn storyboard illustrations, complete with AI-generated social media captions.

What is ClipSketch AI?

Section titled “What is ClipSketch AI?”

ClipSketch AI is an AI-powered content creation workstation designed specifically for video creators, social media operators, and remix enthusiasts. It goes beyond simple video playback by integrating frame-level marking with Google Gemini’s latest multimodal large models to generate hand-drawn style storyboards and viral social media copy.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureClipSketch AITraditional Workflow
Video SourcesBilibili + XiaohongshuManual Download
Frame PrecisionMillisecond-level MarkingApproximate
Art GenerationAI Hand-Drawn StyleManual Artwork
Caption Writing3 AI StylesManual Writing
CostFree (API Key)$10-50/mo Tools
Open SourceMIT LicenseProprietary

Technical Stack

Section titled “Technical Stack”
  • Frontend: React 19 with TypeScript
  • Styling: Tailwind CSS 3
  • AI Engine: Google GenAI SDK with Gemini 2.0 Pro
  • Storage: IndexedDB for local state persistence
  • Utilities: JSZip for packaging, Canvas API for screenshots

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Powerful Video Acquisition

Section titled “1. Powerful Video Acquisition”

ClipSketch AI supports direct importing from popular Chinese social platforms:

  • Multi-Source Import: Parse sharing links from Bilibili and Xiaohongshu (supports short links and mixed text)
  • HD Playback: Adaptive layout optimization for vertical (9:16) and widescreen videos
  • Precise Control: Keyboard shortcuts (Space for play/pause, arrow keys for frame-by-frame or smart stepping)

2. Frame-Level Marking System

Section titled “2. Frame-Level Marking System”

The built-in marking system provides professional-grade precision:

  • Millisecond Recording: Capture every highlight moment with precision
  • Shortcut Tagging: Press T key to quickly mark frames
  • Data Export: Export timeline labels as TXT or package tagged frames as ZIP image packages

3. AI Art Studio (Powered by Gemini)

Section titled “3. AI Art Studio (Powered by Gemini)”

The heart of ClipSketch AI is its AI-powered creative suite:

Intelligent Drawing

Section titled “Intelligent Drawing”

Uses the gemini-2.0-flash-exp model to transform multiple tagged frames into a cohesive, cute hand-drawn style storyboard.

Social Caption Generation

Section titled “Social Caption Generation”

Leverages gemini-2.0-flash-exp to automatically generate 3 different styles of viral copy:

  • Emotional Story: Engaging narrative-driven content
  • Tutorial Style: Practical how-to guides
  • Short & Punchy: Concise, impact-focused copy

Character Fusion

Section titled “Character Fusion”

Upload custom characters/avatars, and the AI automatically integrates them into storyboard scenes.

Cover Generation

Section titled “Cover Generation”

Create high-quality vertical video covers based on selected copy and original frames.

Batch Refinement

Section titled “Batch Refinement”

Support batch generation and optimization of storyboards (configurable to use Batch API for cost savings).

4. Cross-Platform Adaptation

Section titled “4. Cross-Platform Adaptation”
  • Responsive Design: Perfect for PC widescreen, iPad tablet, and mobile vertical operation
  • Mobile Optimization: Automatically switches to vertical layout on phones for intuitive operation

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Node.js (v18+)
  • A valid Google Gemini API Key

Installation and Usage

Section titled “Installation and Usage”

Visit http://localhost:3000 to access the application.

Usage Workflow

Section titled “Usage Workflow”

  1. Import Video: Copy Bilibili or Xiaohongshu share link (text included is fine), paste into the input box, click “Import Video”

  2. Mark Material: Use Space to control playback, ←/→ to adjust progress. When you see a highlight, click Tag button or press keyboard T key

  3. Enter AI Studio: After marking, click “Next: AI Drawing” at the bottom of the list on the right

  4. Create Content:

    • Paste your Gemini API Key in the upper right (if not configured in environment variables)
    • Creative Analysis: AI analyzes video steps
    • Image Generation: Generate hand-drawn storyboards, optionally fusing custom characters
    • Storyboard Refinement: HD redrawing of each frame (supports batch mode)
    • Copy & Cover: Generate social media copy and create matching covers

  5. Export & Share: Download generated storyboard images, covers, or package all materials. One-click copy your favorite copy.

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

API Requirements

Section titled “API Requirements”

Using AI drawing features requires your API Key to have access to the gemini-2.0-flash-exp model. If you encounter a 403 error, check your Google Cloud project settings.

Cross-Origin Playback

Section titled “Cross-Origin Playback”

To support external video link playback and screenshots, this project uses specific proxy strategies and referrerPolicy="no-referrer".

Live Demo

Section titled “Live Demo”

Try ClipSketch AI online: clipsketch-ai.vercel.app

License & Repository

Section titled “License & Repository”
  • License: MIT License
  • GitHub: RanFeng/clipsketch-ai
  • Languages: TypeScript (99.1%), HTML (0.9%)

This open-source tool represents the growing trend of AI-assisted content creation, empowering creators to produce engaging visual stories without traditional artistic barriers. Whether you’re a social media operator, content creator, or remix enthusiast, ClipSketch AI offers a free, powerful alternative to commercial content creation tools.

item.title: ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows
item.content:encoded:
ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Section titled “ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows”

Claude Code, Anthropic’s official CLI tool for AI-assisted development, has a powerful automation system through its .claude configuration files. However, creating complex workflows with multiple sub-agents, conditional branching, and user interactions requires editing markdown and YAML files manually. ClaudeCode Workflow Studio (cc-wf-studio) by breaking-brake brings a visual, drag-and-drop editor to VSCode, making workflow creation intuitive and accessible.

What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?

Section titled “What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio is a VSCode extension that provides a visual workflow editor for Claude Code. It allows you to:

  • Design workflows visually - Drag and drop nodes onto a canvas
  • Configure without code - Set up sub-agents, skills, and MCP tools through a UI
  • Export with one click - Generate .claude/agents/ and .claude/commands/ files automatically
  • Collaborate with your team - Share workflows via Slack with preview cards

GitHub Repository: breaking-brake/cc-wf-studio VSCode Marketplace: Open VSX License: AGPL-3.0-or-later Version: 3.9.1 (as of December 2025)

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Visual Workflow Editor

Section titled “1. Visual Workflow Editor”

The core of cc-wf-studio is its drag-and-drop canvas. Instead of writing markdown and YAML, you visually connect nodes to define workflow logic:

  • Prompt Nodes - Define reusable prompt templates with {{variable}} substitution
  • Sub-Agent Nodes - Configure autonomous AI agents with custom system prompts and tool permissions
  • Skill Nodes - Integrate Claude Code Skills from personal or project directories
  • MCP Nodes - Connect to Model Context Protocol tools for external integrations
  • Control Flow Nodes - IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)

2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement

Section titled “2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement”

One of the standout features is AI-assisted refinement. Instead of generating workflows from scratch once, you can iteratively improve them through conversation:

  1. Click the “Edit with AI” button (✨ sparkle icon)
  2. Describe your changes in natural language (max 2000 characters)
  3. The AI modifies your workflow incrementally, preserving existing work
  4. Repeat until satisfied

This conversational approach builds workflows through multiple rounds of feedback, with the AI maintaining conversation history and applying changes incrementally.

Example prompts:

  • “Add a Sub-Agent node that validates the input data”
  • “Connect the error handler to a logging Sub-Agent”
  • “Change the AskUserQuestion node to have 3 options: High, Medium, Low”

3. One-Click Export

Section titled “3. One-Click Export”

When your workflow is ready, click Export to generate:

  • .claude/agents/*.md - Sub-Agent definitions with system prompts and tool configurations
  • .claude/commands/*.md - SlashCommand definitions that execute the entire workflow

The exported files are ready to use immediately with Claude Code CLI. No manual editing required.

4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)

Section titled “4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)”

For teams, cc-wf-studio offers Slack integration:

  • Export workflows to Slack channels with preview cards
  • One-click import links for team members
  • Seamless collaboration without leaving your chat workspace

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)

Section titled “From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)”
  1. Open VSCode Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X / Cmd+Shift+X)
  2. Search for “Claude Code Workflow Studio”
  3. Click Install

From Open VSX

Section titled “From Open VSX”

The extension is also available on Open VSX:

  1. Install the Open VSX extension
  2. Search for “cc-wf-studio”
  3. Click Install

From Source

Section titled “From Source”

  1. Clone the repository:

  2. Install dependencies:

  3. Build the extension:

  4. Package and install:

  5. Install the generated .vsix file through VSCode’s “Install from VSIX…” option

Quick Start Guide

Section titled “Quick Start Guide”

1. Open the Editor

Section titled “1. Open the Editor”
  • Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P
  • Type “Claude Code Workflow Studio: Open Editor”
  • Press Enter

First-time users get an interactive onboarding tour (available in English, Japanese, Korean, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese).

2. Create Your Workflow

Section titled “2. Create Your Workflow”

The left palette is organized into sections:

  • Basic Nodes: Prompt (templates), Sub-Agent (AI tasks)
  • Control Flow: IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)
  • Integration: Skill (Claude Code Skills), MCP (external tools)

Steps:

  1. Drag nodes from the palette onto the canvas
  2. Click a node to edit its properties in the right panel
  3. Connect nodes by dragging from output ports (right) to input ports (left)
  4. Configure node-specific settings (prompts, variables, conditions)

3. Save & Export

Section titled “3. Save & Export”
  • Enter a workflow name in the toolbar
  • Click Save to store as JSON in .vscode/workflows/
  • Click Export to generate .claude files

Node Types Deep Dive

Section titled “Node Types Deep Dive”

Prompt Nodes

Section titled “Prompt Nodes”

Define reusable prompt templates with template variables:

Variables are automatically detected and validated. At runtime, values are dynamically substituted.

Sub-Agent Nodes

Section titled “Sub-Agent Nodes”

Configure autonomous AI agents with:

  • System Prompt - Custom instructions for the agent
  • Tool Permissions - Choose which tools the agent can access (Read, Write, Bash, etc.)
  • Model Selection - Sonnet (balanced), Opus (complex tasks), Haiku (speed)

Skill Nodes

Section titled “Skill Nodes”

Integrate Claude Code Skills into your workflows:

  • Personal Skills - From ~/.claude/skills/ for individual use
  • Project Skills - From .claude/skills/ for team collaboration
  • Create New Skills - Build skills directly from the visual editor with a guided form
  • Browse & Select - Interactive skill browser with descriptions

MCP Nodes

Section titled “MCP Nodes”

Integrate Model Context Protocol tools:

  1. Select an MCP server from the dropdown (configured in Claude Code)
  2. Browse available tools or use search to filter
  3. Configure parameters with dynamic form generation based on tool schemas
  4. Real-time validation with error messages

Prerequisites: MCP servers must be configured in Claude Code settings first.

Control Flow Nodes

Section titled “Control Flow Nodes”

IfElse Node

Section titled “IfElse Node”

Fixed 2-way branching for binary conditions (True/False, Yes/No, Success/Error).

Switch Node

Section titled “Switch Node”

Variable multi-way branching (2-N branches) with dynamic case management. Ideal for complex routing logic.

Usage Examples

Section titled “Usage Examples”

Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow

Section titled “Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow”
  1. Upload Document Prompt - Asks user for file path
  2. PDF Extractor Skill (Personal) - Extracts text from PDF files
  3. Ask User - “Processing type?” → Summarize / Translate / Analyze
  4. Document Processor Skill (Project) - Team-shared processing logic
  5. Format Results Sub-Agent - Creates final output

Example 2: Code Quality Scanner

Section titled “Example 2: Code Quality Scanner”
  1. Code Scanner Sub-Agent - Identifies issues
  2. Ask User - “Priority level?” → Critical Only / All Issues
  3. Filter Results Sub-Agent
  4. Generate Fix Suggestions Sub-Agent

Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright

Section titled “Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright”
  1. Input URL Prompt - Asks user for target website
  2. Playwright Navigate MCP Tool - Opens browser and navigates to URL
  3. Ask User - “Action type?” → Screenshot / Extract Text / Click Element
  4. Playwright Action MCP Tool - Performs the selected browser action
  5. Process Results Sub-Agent - Analyzes and formats output

Internationalization

Section titled “Internationalization”

The Visual Editor UI and all exported files automatically adapt to your VSCode display language setting (vscode.env.language). Supported languages:

  • English (default)
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Simplified Chinese (zh-CN)
  • Traditional Chinese (zh-TW/zh-HK)

This ensures both the editing experience and generated workflows are accessible for international teams.

Limitations

Section titled “Limitations”
  • Maximum 50 nodes per workflow
  • AI processing timeout (default 90 seconds, configurable: 30s-5min)
  • Request limited to 2000 characters for AI refinement
  • Conversation history stored only during active session
  • Requires active Claude Code CLI installation

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Workflow won’t save

  • Ensure workflow name contains only letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores
  • Check all required fields are filled
  • Look for error messages in VSCode notifications

Export fails

  • Verify all nodes have valid configurations
  • Ensure node names are unique
  • Check write permissions for .claude directory

Can’t load workflow

  • Click refresh button (↻) to update the list
  • Verify file exists in .vscode/workflows/
  • Check JSON file isn’t corrupted

License

Section titled “License”

This project is licensed under the GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 (AGPL-3.0-or-later).

Key points:

  • You can use, modify, and distribute the software
  • If you modify and deploy (including as a network service), you must make source code available under AGPL-3.0
  • Commercial use is allowed, but proprietary modifications are not

Copyright (c) 2025 breaking-brake

Acknowledgments

Section titled “Acknowledgments”

Built with React Flow • Powered by Claude Code • Inspired by Dify

Why This Matters

Section titled “Why This Matters”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio bridges the gap between technical power and accessibility. By bringing visual programming to Claude Code workflows, it:

  1. Lowers the barrier to entry - No need to understand markdown/YAML structure
  2. Accelerates development - Visual feedback reduces trial-and-error
  3. Enables collaboration - Teams can share and review workflows visually
  4. Integrates seamlessly - Exports work directly with Claude Code CLI

As the Claude Code ecosystem continues to evolve, tools like cc-wf-studio demonstrate how community extensions can enhance the core platform’s capabilities.

Claude Usage Tracker: Native macOS Menu Bar App for Real-Time Claude AI Usage Monitoring

Section titled “Claude Usage Tracker: Native macOS Menu Bar App for Real-Time Claude AI Usage Monitoring”

For Claude AI power users, keeping track of usage limits is crucial—especially when working with the premium Opus model. Claude Usage Tracker is a beautifully crafted, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits, built entirely with Swift and SwiftUI.

Official Apple code signed • macOS 14.0+ • ~3 MB • MIT License

What is Claude Usage Tracker?

Section titled “What is Claude Usage Tracker?”

Claude Usage Tracker is a lightweight, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits. Unlike web-based solutions, this app runs natively on your Mac with:

  • Real-Time Monitoring: Track session (5-hour), weekly, and API console usage
  • Official Apple Code Signing: No security warnings—installs like any normal Mac app
  • Automatic Updates: Built-in Sparkle-powered update system
  • Developer Integration: Terminal statusline for Claude Code users
  • Privacy-First: Local storage, no telemetry, no cloud sync

item.title: VoiceFlow: Free Local AI Voice Dictation That Never Sends Your Data to the Cloud
item.content:encoded:
Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?

Section titled “Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?”

Cloud dictation services have become the norm, but they come with significant trade-offs: monthly subscription fees ($10-15/month), complete dependence on internet connectivity, and the uncomfortable reality that your voice data is processed on remote servers.

VoiceFlow by infiniV offers a compelling alternative. This open-source Windows application brings OpenAI’s powerful Whisper speech recognition model directly to your local machine. Every word you speak is processed entirely on your hardware—your voice data never leaves your device.

What is VoiceFlow?

Section titled “What is VoiceFlow?”

VoiceFlow is a free, open-source voice dictation application for Windows 10/11 that leverages OpenAI’s Whisper model for speech-to-text conversion. Unlike cloud-based alternatives, VoiceFlow runs 100% locally on your computer, ensuring complete privacy and eliminating ongoing costs.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureVoiceFlowCloud Services
Cost$0.00$10-15/mo
Data Privacy100% LocalCloud Processed
Offline SupportFull CapabilityNone
LatencyReal-timeNetwork Dependent
Account RequiredNoYes
Open SourceMIT LicenseProprietary

Technical Highlights

Section titled “Technical Highlights”
  • 16+ Whisper Models: Choose from Tiny (75MB) to Large-v3 (3GB), including Turbo models optimized for daily use
  • 99+ Language Support: Automatic language detection built-in
  • Custom Hotkeys: Configure shortcuts with Hold or Toggle recording modes
  • Local History: SQLite database stores searchable transcriptions locally
  • Auto-Paste: Text appears directly at your cursor—no copy-paste needed
  • GPU Support: Recent updates add GPU acceleration for faster inference

Privacy First Design

Section titled “Privacy First Design”

VoiceFlow’s architecture prioritizes privacy at every level:

  • Air-Gapped Safe: Works completely offline after initial model download
  • Open Source: Every line of code is auditable on GitHub
  • No Telemetry: Zero tracking, zero analytics, zero cloud calls
  • RAM-Only Processing: Microphone data never touches disk during processing

How VoiceFlow Works

Section titled “How VoiceFlow Works”

The application operates with elegant simplicity:

  1. Ready: VoiceFlow waits silently in your system tray with minimal presence
  2. Listening: Activate with your hotkey and speak naturally. Audio stays in RAM only with real-time amplitude visualization
  3. Transcribe & Paste: Release the hotkey. Local AI processes your audio instantly, then auto-pastes text at your cursor

Recording Modes

Section titled “Recording Modes”
  • Hold Mode: Hold to record, release to transcribe. Perfect for quick dictation bursts
  • Toggle Mode: Press once to start, press again to stop. Ideal for longer recordings

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Quick Install (Recommended)

Section titled “Quick Install (Recommended)”

Download the Windows installer from the official releases page:

Build from Source

Section titled “Build from Source”

For developers who want to customize or contribute:

Architecture

Section titled “Architecture”
LayerTechnology
CorePyloid (PySide6 + QtWebEngine)
Inferencefaster-whisper (CTranslate2)
FrontendReact 18, Vite, Tailwind CSS v4
UIshadcn/ui, Lucide React

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

VoiceFlow is ideal for:

  • Privacy-Conscious Professionals: Lawyers, doctors, and journalists handling sensitive information
  • Remote Workers: Needing reliable dictation without network dependency
  • Students: Lecture notes and study materials without subscription costs
  • Developers: Coding documentation and commit messages hands-free
  • Content Creators: Drafting articles and scripts without privacy concerns

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”

vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)

Section titled “vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)”

VoiceFlow eliminates the monthly fees and removes any privacy concerns associated with cloud processing. You also get true offline capability.

vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations

Section titled “vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations”
  • winWhisper: VoiceFlow offers a more streamlined, always-ready experience with system tray integration
  • Buzz: VoiceFlow’s hotkey system and auto-paste provide smoother workflow integration
  • Whisper Desktop: VoiceFlow has a more modern UI with additional features like local history search

Precautions and Limitations

Section titled “Precautions and Limitations”
  • Platform: Currently Windows-only (10/11 64-bit)
  • Initial Download: First run requires downloading Whisper models (75MB - 3GB depending on model choice)
  • Hardware Requirements: Larger models may require more RAM and benefit from GPU acceleration
  • Language Accuracy: While 99+ languages are supported, accuracy varies by model size and language

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is VoiceFlow really free? A: Yes, completely free and open-source under the MIT License.

Q: Does it work offline? A: Yes, after the initial model download, it works completely offline.

Q: How accurate is the transcription? A: Accuracy depends on the model chosen. Large-v3 offers near-human accuracy, while Turbo provides the best speed-to-quality ratio for daily use.

Q: Can I use it for other languages? A: Yes, VoiceFlow supports 99+ languages with automatic detection.

Q: Does it store my voice recordings? A: No, microphone data is processed in RAM only and never stored. Only transcriptions are saved locally to the SQLite history database.

Future Development

Section titled “Future Development”

VoiceFlow is actively developed with recent updates including GPU support. Potential future enhancements may include:

  • Additional language model optimizations
  • Cross-platform support (macOS, Linux)
  • Advanced text processing features
  • Integration with other productivity tools

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

VoiceFlow represents a shift towards user-controlled AI tools. By bringing powerful speech recognition directly to your Windows machine without cloud dependencies or privacy trade-offs, it offers a compelling alternative to subscription-based cloud services.

Whether you’re a privacy advocate, a budget-conscious professional, or simply someone who values software independence, VoiceFlow delivers professional-grade voice dictation without the hidden costs.

Section titled “Reference Links”

  • Latest Release Download
  • OpenAI Whisper
  • Reddit Discussion

item.content:encoded:
Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Section titled “Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude”

When Mitchell Hashimoto, founder of Ghostty (the modern, GPU-accelerated terminal emulator), wanted to improve the macOS update feature, he didn’t just write code — he had a conversation. In a remarkable session he calls “vibe coding,” Mitchell paired with Claude to iteratively improve the codebase through dialogue, exploration, and shared discovery.

This isn’t about AI replacing developers. It’s about AI as a collaborative partner — and the transcript shows something beautiful: the AI catches things humans miss, the human provides direction and context, and together they build something better than either could alone.

What is “Vibe Coding”?

Section titled “What is “Vibe Coding”?”

Vibe coding is a conversational approach to software development where the developer and AI work together through natural dialogue. Rather than treating the AI as a command-execution tool, the developer treats it as a pair programmer — discussing, exploring, and iterating together.

In Mitchell’s session, captured from a real coding conversation on AmpCode, the flow goes like this:

  1. Oracle Consultation — Ask Claude to analyze code for improvements
  2. Discussion — Talk through the findings, make decisions together
  3. Implementation — Write code with Claude’s assistance
  4. Iteration — Learn from failures, adjust approach, try again
  5. Testing — Verify changes work, add tests for confidence

The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature

Section titled “The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature”

Mitchell started with a simple request: “Are there any other improvements you can see to be made with the @macos/Sources/Features/ Update feature? Don’t write any code. Consult the oracle.”

The “oracle” — Claude in analysis mode — identified several categories of improvements:

Critical Safety Issues

Section titled “Critical Safety Issues”
  1. Retain cycle in UpdateDriver.showUpdaterError — The retry closure captured self strongly, creating a memory leak
  2. Threading issues — UI-facing types should be marked @MainActor
  3. Progress value bugs — Progress values needed clamping to [0, 1] to prevent visual glitches
  4. Uncancellable timer — The “No Updates” auto-dismiss task could fire stale updates
  5. Swallowed errors — try? hid potential failures in startUpdater()

Areas Needing Unit Tests

Section titled “Areas Needing Unit Tests”
  1. ReleaseNotes parsing — Semver detection, git hash handling, edge cases
  2. UpdateState Equatable — Equality tests for downloading/error states
  3. ViewModel formatting — Text/icon/color mappings for each state
  4. Progress math — Division by zero, nil values, overshoot scenarios
  5. Auto-dismiss timing — Verify transitions and task cancellation

UX Improvements

Section titled “UX Improvements”
  • Add accessibility labels for assistive technologies
  • Clamp/abbreviate long error messages to prevent UI overflow

The Conversational Dance

Section titled “The Conversational Dance”

What makes this session remarkable is the back-and-forth:

Mitchell: “Stop stop stop. Undo all the main actor stuff.”

Claude: “Done! I’ve reverted all the @MainActor changes. The build now succeeds…”

Mitchell: “For the error message, instead of truncating, isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way to do this?”

Claude: “You’re absolutely right! SwiftUI has .lineLimit() and .truncationMode() for this…”

The human provides course correction when the AI goes down a problematic path. The AI suggests better approaches when the human asks questions. They learn from each other.

Key Improvements Made

Section titled “Key Improvements Made”

1. Fixed Retain Cycle

Section titled “1. Fixed Retain Cycle”

2. Clamped Progress Values

Section titled “2. Clamped Progress Values”

3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable

Section titled “3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable”

4. Added Accessibility Labels

Section titled “4. Added Accessibility Labels”

Simple, but critical — assistive technologies can now announce update status to visually impaired users.

5. Comprehensive Unit Tests

Section titled “5. Comprehensive Unit Tests”

The session added three new test files:

  • UpdateStateTests.swift — 150+ lines testing Equatable conformance for all states
  • UpdateViewModelTests.swift — 300+ lines testing formatting (text, icons, colors)
  • ProgressTests.swift — 150+ lines testing progress math edge cases

What This Session Teaches Us

Section titled “What This Session Teaches Us”

1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss

Section titled “1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss”

The oracle caught a retain cycle and progress value bugs that weren’t obvious. Code review tools often miss these too — having an AI analyze the code with fresh eyes catches different classes of issues.

2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment

Section titled “2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment”

When the AI suggested marking everything @MainActor, Mitchell recognized this would cause cascading compilation issues and asked to revert. Human judgment about architecture and trade-offs remains essential.

3. Iteration is Learning

Section titled “3. Iteration is Learning”

The session goes through multiple attempts:

  • First attempt at @MainActor fails → revert and try different approach
  • Manual error truncation → “isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way?” → use .truncationMode()

Each failure teaches something. The conversation enables rapid iteration.

4. Tests Provide Confidence

Section titled “4. Tests Provide Confidence”

The oracle suggested comprehensive unit tests. Writing tests alongside fixes ensures the improvements work correctly and prevents regressions.

5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought

Section titled “5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought”

The UX improvements weren’t flashy features — they were accessibility labels and proper text truncation. These make the software usable for everyone.

The Vibe Coding Workflow

Section titled “The Vibe Coding Workflow”

Based on Mitchell’s session, here’s a pattern for vibe coding:

  1. Ask, Don’t Command — “What improvements do you see?” vs “Fix this bug”
  2. Discuss Before Implementing — Talk through the findings, understand the why
  3. Implement Incrementally — Make one change at a time, verify it works
  4. Course Correct — Don’t be afraid to say “stop, undo that”
  5. Add Tests — Build confidence through test coverage
  6. Celebrate Learning — Each failure is a learning opportunity

Tools Used

Section titled “Tools Used”
  • Claude Code — AI pair programmer for the conversation
  • Swift/SwiftUI — Ghostty’s macOS frontend
  • Sparkle — macOS update framework
  • Swift Testing — Modern testing framework

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Original Thread: AmpCode - Potential improvements for macos update feature
  • Ghostty: ghostty.org
  • Mitchell Hashimoto: @mitchellh on AmpCode

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Vibe coding isn’t about AI writing code for you. It’s about having a conversation with code — where the AI brings analytical superpowers, the human brings judgment and context, and together they create something better.

Mitchell’s session shows the future of programming: not humans replaced by AI, but humans augmented by AI — working together, learning from each other, and building better software through conversation.

The improvements to Ghostty’s update feature — safer code, better tests, improved accessibility — are a testament to what’s possible when developers embrace AI as a collaborative partner rather than a mere tool.

item.title: Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity
item.content:encoded:
Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity

Section titled “Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity”

“This project is underrated. I’ve found it to be useful and fun” — Hamel Husain

“Biggest increase in productivity since Cursor” — Luke Harries

AI coding agents have transformed how developers work, but getting the most out of them requires more than just prompting. Based on the Vibe Kanban project, here’s a comprehensive guide to orchestrating AI coding agents effectively.

Planning: Always Start with a Plan

Section titled “Planning: Always Start with a Plan”

Five minutes spent planning saves ten minutes in review.

Regardless of task size, always begin with a plan. Whether your agent has a built-in “plan mode” or not, you can simply ask:

“Come up with a plan, confirm with me before making changes.”

Planning can feel like overhead, but it moves unavoidable work earlier. A plan is faster to judge than a diff.

Planning Sets the Shape

Section titled “Planning Sets the Shape”

Agents optimize for getting something working with minimal edits. Once that version exists, subsequent changes patch whatever’s there already—instead of rethinking the approach. The plan is your chance to pick the right shape before the code hardens around the wrong one.

Async Workflows: Juggle Multiple Threads

Section titled “Async Workflows: Juggle Multiple Threads”

Working asynchronously with coding agents (sometimes called “backgrounding”) lets you:

  • Juggle multiple threads at once
  • Avoid drifting into procrastination
  • Keep the agent running for longer stretches while you do other things

A typical workflow: keep the agent running continuously while you handle other tasks, checking in periodically.

Use YOLO Mode for True Async

Section titled “Use YOLO Mode for True Async”

Async only works if you’re not approving every tool call. Either use your agent’s YOLO mode, or give it an explicit allowlist of commands that covers almost everything it needs.

Otherwise you’ve reinvented pair programming—except slower.

Naming varies by platform: ‘yolo’, ‘dangerously skip permissions’, or similar.

Set Your Codebase Up to Be QA’d

Section titled “Set Your Codebase Up to Be QA’d”

If the agent can’t test its own changes, it’ll ask you to do it—which isn’t a great use of your time.

Put in the work to make changes verifiable with a dev or test command. Not everything is testable by an agent (frontend still needs human eyes), but most changes should end with “tests pass,” not “can you try this?”

Solve Dev Servers

Section titled “Solve Dev Servers”

Agents are bad at starting and cleaning up dev servers, which leads to:

  • Port conflicts
  • Wasted effort troubleshooting “something’s already running on that port” errors

Solutions like Dev Manager MCP assign ports and kill stale servers automatically.

Add Dummy Data for Offline Testing

Section titled “Add Dummy Data for Offline Testing”

Make it easy to run the project offline with realistic seed data. If the agent spends half its time getting the app into a testable state, you’ll get:

  • Flaky results
  • Slower progress

Dummy data also enables parallel agents—if they share a real database, one might work on a different schema version than another.

Combating Agent Laziness

Section titled “Combating Agent Laziness”

Coding agents make some lazy decisions repeatedly. Here’s what to watch for:

No Backwards Compatibility

Section titled “No Backwards Compatibility”

Every coding agent defaults to maintaining backwards compatibility. This is part overcaution, part laziness—keeping the old interface means not refactoring all call sites.

Add this to your system prompt:

We want the simplest change possible. We don’t care about migration. Code readability matters most, and we’re happy to make bigger changes to achieve it.

Disable Disabling Lint Rules

Section titled “Disable Disabling Lint Rules”

Agents love silencing linter errors instead of fixing them. eslint-disable-next-line and similar patterns appear across TypeScript, Rust, and likely other languages.

Ban this with plugins like eslint-comments/no-restricted-disable.

Frontend Best Practices

Section titled “Frontend Best Practices”

Separate Presentation from Logic

Section titled “Separate Presentation from Logic”

Keep leaf components presentational. Business logic (fetching data, etc.) lives in parent components.

Most frontend problems with agents involve Frankenstein components: thousands of lines of state management mixed with rendering. Separating concerns makes it easy to audit a presentational component’s props and spot irregularities.

It also helps the agent—agents look for patterns to follow. Clear folder structures give them distinct examples.

This can be semi-enforced via ESLint by disabling hooks like useState or useEffect in presentational components:

Restrict Tailwind

Section titled “Restrict Tailwind”

Agents love adding custom colors, spacing, and padding everywhere. Enforce a small set of allowed utility classes via ESLint. For example, p-4 and p-8 might be banned, but p-base and p-double are allowed and defined in your Tailwind config.

Use Figma MCP for Presentational Components

Section titled “Use Figma MCP for Presentational Components”

The Figma MCP server is excellent for a first pass at presentational components. Select a component in Figma, then prompt:

  • The component has been designed in Figma and can be retrieved using the Figma MCP server
  • All spacing, colors, and sizes should match existing Tailwind variables
  • We use [icon library]
  • If you cannot match an existing variable, ask the user what to do

Key Takeaways

Section titled “Key Takeaways”
PracticeBenefit
Always plan firstFaster to review plans than diffs
Use async workflowsJuggle multiple threads simultaneously
Enable YOLO modeTrue async, not slow pair programming
Make code QA-ableAgent can verify its own changes
Solve dev serversAvoid port conflicts and wasted time
Add dummy dataOffline testing + parallel agents
Break backwards compatibilityCleaner, more readable code
Enforce lint rulesFix root causes, don’t silence warnings
Separate concernsAvoid Frankenstein components
Use Figma MCPQuick presentational component passes

Getting Started with Vibe Kanban

Section titled “Getting Started with Vibe Kanban”

Vibe Kanban is an open-source project implementing these principles. Version 0.0.142 (released December 22, 2025) includes the latest features for AI coding agent orchestration.

The project is currently hiring—check out their careers page if you’re interested in building the future of AI-assisted development.

This guide is based on the official Vibe Guide from the Vibe Kanban project.

item.title: BMAD Method: How to Turn LLM System Prompts into a Reproducible AI Dev Team
item.content:encoded:
BMAD Method is an open-source AI-driven agile development methodology and toolkit based on the BMAD Core framework. It includes 19 professional AI Agents and 50+ Workflows covering the complete lifecycle from requirements analysis, planning, and architecture design to development and testing. It has garnered 23.6k stars on GitHub (as of December 2025). It packages system prompts, role definitions, and process instructions into structured assets, allowing you to orchestrate a team of AI experts working together like a real software development team, rather than copying and pasting fragmented prompts.

Why Do You Need a Systematic System Prompt Repository?

Section titled “Why Do You Need a Systematic System Prompt Repository?”

Most AI learners and developers encounter these pain points when using large language models:

  • Disorganized system prompts: You write a good system prompt in Claude today, modify it in ChatGPT tomorrow, and end up with prompts scattered across conversations and documents, unable to find the best version.
  • Unstable AI roles: Sometimes you want it to be a product manager, sometimes an architect, sometimes QA, but you have to re-explain each time with inconsistent results and unstable output quality.
  • Lack of closed-loop from requirements to code: Even if you’ve written many prompts, they’re mostly one-off: requirements documents have one style, architecture discussions another, development and testing yet another. These prompts lack strict artifact flow relationships, making it hard to form a replicable engineering process.
  • High collaboration costs: When you want to share your collection of prompts with colleagues, they can only copy from a long document or Notion page one by one—completely non-toolified.

If you’ve experienced similar issues, what BMAD Method does can be understood as:

Engineering, versioning, and portable AI system prompts + role division + process steps, transforming them into an AI team framework that can be repeatedly reused across various IDEs and AI tools.

What is BMAD Method Essentially?

Section titled “What is BMAD Method Essentially?”

The positioning of BMAD Method can be summarized in one sentence:

Breakthrough Method for Agile AI-Driven Development — A framework that enables AI to participate in development as an agile team.

Its core has three layers:

  • BMAD Core: A foundational framework designed for human + multi-agent collaboration, containing:

    • Agents (professional role personas) written in Markdown
    • Agent Teams composed of multiple agents
    • Workflows (strategic processes) defined in YAML
    • Templates with LLM instructions (PRD, architecture documents, Story files, etc.)

  • BMAD Method: Built on top of BMAD Core, focusing on software development workflows, breaking down the entire chain from analysis → planning → solution → implementation into multiple stages and artifacts, completed by different agents in relay.

  • BMAD Builder / Creative Intelligence Suite:

    • BMAD Builder: Allows you to design your own professional agents and modules on the same framework (e.g., legal, finance, education fields).
    • Creative Intelligence Suite: Provides creative thinking and brainstorming workflows to assist product innovation and narrative design.

In other words, BMAD Method is not just a simple prompt collection. It structures system prompts by:

  • Roles (who does it)
  • Stages (when to do it)
  • Artifacts (what to produce)
  • Tools (where to use them)

All structured into an engineering methodology and code repository that can be ported to your project.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. 19 Professional AI Roles to Build a Virtual Development Team

Section titled “1. 19 Professional AI Roles to Build a Virtual Development Team”

BMAD includes a small virtual company:

  • Analyst
  • Product Manager
  • Architect
  • Scrum Master
  • Product Owner
  • Developer
  • QA Engineer
  • UX Designer, Game Designer, Tech Writer, etc.

Each role has:

  • Clear responsibilities
  • Corresponding commands (such as @analyst, @pm, @dev)
  • Corresponding document types to produce (PRD, architecture specs, Story files, QA reports)

These definitions are written in Markdown + system prompts—you don’t need to reinvent how to make a model play a qualified product manager—just call the existing persona directly.

2. 50+ Workflows Covering the Complete Development Lifecycle

Section titled “2. 50+ Workflows Covering the Complete Development Lifecycle”

BMAD Method breaks down the entire software delivery process into 4 stages:

  1. Analysis: Requirements discovery, market research, solution comparison
  2. Planning: PRD, technical specs, game design documents, etc.
  3. Solutioning: System architecture, data flow, API design, UX sketches
  4. Implementation: Story-driven development, code implementation, testing verification

For each stage, the framework provides multiple workflows defined in YAML form with process and call order. For example:

  • Use Analyst to generate Project Brief
  • Use PM to generate PRD
  • Use Architect to generate Architecture document
  • Use PO for document sharding
  • Use SM to generate Story files
  • Use Developer/QA for implementation and verification

This is essentially an executable system prompt process, not a bunch of scattered prompt examples.

3. Scale-Adaptive Intelligence: Three Intelligence Tracks

Section titled “3. Scale-Adaptive Intelligence: Three Intelligence Tracks”

BMAD provides three intelligence tracks:

  • Quick Flow: Suitable for bug fixes and small requirements, generating lightweight technical specs, ready to code in minutes.
  • BMad Method Standard Track: For new features, new products, or medium-sized platforms, from PRD to architecture to UX.
  • Enterprise Track: For projects with high compliance, governance requirements, providing more complete documentation, quality gates, and processes.

In practice, you can run *workflow-init to let BMAD automatically recommend the appropriate track based on goals and context.

4. Story / Sharding System: Documents as First-Class Engineering Citizens

Section titled “4. Story / Sharding System: Documents as First-Class Engineering Citizens”

BMAD emphasizes document sharding and Story file systems:

  • Break large PRDs into multiple Epic files
  • Generate Story files with complete context from Epics (e.g., 1.1.user-registration.story.md)
  • Story files include:
    • Architecture background
    • Implementation details
    • Acceptance criteria
    • Related constraints

Finally, Developer and QA work around Story files—creating a strict mapping between system prompts + documents + code, facilitating version control, auditing, and rollback.

5. Modular Architecture Based on BMAD Core

Section titled “5. Modular Architecture Based on BMAD Core”

At the framework level, BMAD explicitly divides itself into several modules:

  • Agents: Markdown persona definitions (essentially structured system prompts)
  • Agent Teams: Reusable team combinations
  • Workflows: YAML process definitions
  • Templates: Document templates with embedded LLM instructions
  • Expansion Packs: Extensions for specific fields (creative, business, education, health, etc.)

This means: if you’re working on organizing LLM system prompts, you can directly follow this directory structure and abstraction approach, building your prompt repository on the same architecture.

6. IDE & Toolchain Integration

Section titled “6. IDE & Toolchain Integration”

BMAD is not a framework that only works in a specific web page—it has been verified and integrated in many development tools:

  • Supports Cursor, Windsurf, and other AI IDEs via @agent syntax
  • Compatible with VS Code extensions like Cline, RooCode, Augment, Aider
  • Provides command-line tools based on Node.js 20+ (npx bmad-method)
  • Can run complete workflows in browser Web UI

For developers accustomed to asking AI while writing in IDEs, this is much more comfortable than copying and pasting prompts in browser tabs.

7. Token Savings and Update Safety

Section titled “7. Token Savings and Update Safety”

In large projects, you often encounter contexts that are too long and token limits. BMAD’s approach is:

  • Use the document sharding mechanism to feed each agent only the part of the context it needs
  • Official claims up to ~90% token savings (for large projects)

At the same time, the framework is designed with update safety in mind:

  • Your custom configuration is by default placed in directories that won’t be overwritten
  • When upgrading BMAD versions, your personalized agent and workflow settings are preserved

8. Web Bundles and Multi-Model Support

Section titled “8. Web Bundles and Multi-Model Support”

BMAD provides so-called Web Bundles, allowing you to reuse the same set of agent and process definitions on:

  • ChatGPT
  • Claude Projects
  • Gemini Gems

This is very friendly for students researching different LLM performance differences—you can run the same BMAD workflow on different models and compare output quality horizontally.

Technical Architecture: From System Prompts to Executable Processes

Section titled “Technical Architecture: From System Prompts to Executable Processes”

To more intuitively understand BMAD Method’s technical structure, we can summarize each core component in the following table:

ComponentLogical Location / FormContent CarriedRole in System Prompt Engineering
Agentsbmad-core/agents/ (Markdown)Professional role personas, behavior guidelines, communication stylesBreaking long system prompts into role definitions
Agent Teamsbmad-core/agent-teams/Combination configurations of multiple agentsDescribing what an AI team looks like
Workflowsbmad-core/workflows/ (YAML)Multi-stage processes, dependencies, command callsStringing multiple roles and prompts into complete processes
Templatesbmad-core/templates/ (Markdown)PRD, architecture docs, Story templates + LLM instructionsMaking LLMs output artifacts in unified format
Expansion PacksExtension directories / independent modulesDomain-specific agents / workflowsCopying this methodology to other industries

If you’re organizing your own LLM system prompt repository, it’s well worth referencing BMAD’s layered approach: upgrading prompt text into combinations of roles + processes + templates, rather than isolated strings.

From Installation to Running Your First Workflow

Section titled “From Installation to Running Your First Workflow”

Although BMAD looks heavy, it’s actually quite straightforward to get started.

Installation: Pull the Framework into Your Project with One Command

Section titled “Installation: Pull the Framework into Your Project with One Command”

In any project directory, simply run (Node.js 20+):

After installation, a standardized BMAD structure is generated in the project directory, including agents, workflows, templates, etc.

Initialization: Let AI Help You Choose the Development Mode

Section titled “Initialization: Let AI Help You Choose the Development Mode”

Load any agent in a supported IDE, then execute:

BMAD will recommend based on your project goals:

  • Quick Flow
  • Standard BMAD Method
  • Enterprise track

And provide suggested next steps.

A System Prompt Closed-Loop Example from Requirements to Launch

Section titled “A System Prompt Closed-Loop Example from Requirements to Launch”

Based on the official e-commerce example, BMAD’s complete process is roughly as follows:

  1. Analyst: Project Vision and Market Analysis

    • Command example: @analyst Create project brief for modern e-commerce platform
    • Output: project-brief.md

  2. Product Manager: Generate PRD

    • Functional Requirements (FR)
    • Non-Functional Requirements (NFR)
    • Epic list and user story hierarchy
    • Use Analyst’s Brief as input
    • Output: PRD.md

  3. Architect: System Architecture Design

    • Output: architecture.md, including tech stack, system components, data flows, and API specifications.

  4. Product Owner: Document Sharding

    • Break PRD + architecture docs into focused Epic files, such as:
      • epic-1-user-auth.md
      • epic-2-products.md

  5. Scrum Master: Generate Story Files

    • Generate Story files for a specific Epic, such as:
      • 1.1.user-registration.story.md
    • Story includes context, implementation details, acceptance criteria, etc.

  6. Developer: Code Implementation

    • Implement code around Story files (Controllers, components, database migrations, etc.) and generate test cases.

  7. QA: Quality Verification and Tracking

    • Produce a series of QA documents including test strategy, tracking matrix, quality gate reports.

In this entire process, you can see:

  • Each stage corresponds to one or more agents
  • Each agent is backed by a highly structured system prompt
  • Artifacts (documents & code) form strict tracking chains through filenames and directory structures

This is the concrete embodiment of treating system prompts as engineering assets.

Who is BMAD Suitable For?

Section titled “Who is BMAD Suitable For?”

Combined with official documentation and technical articles, BMAD Method is well-suited for the following users and scenarios:

1. AI Learners Wanting to Systematically Organize LLM System Prompts

Section titled “1. AI Learners Wanting to Systematically Organize LLM System Prompts”

You’ve already accumulated many prompts: writing requirements, reviewing code, generating tests, but now they’re scattered across chat history, documents, and your brain.

BMAD provides you with a template for:

  • How to break down roles
  • How to break down stages
  • How to design artifact formats

You can gradually migrate and upgrade your prompt repository within this structure.

2. Small Teams / Startups: Want AI to Truly Participate in the Delivery Loop

Section titled “2. Small Teams / Startups: Want AI to Truly Participate in the Delivery Loop”

For a team of two or three people, hiring a few AI employees is often more realistic than hiring another person. BMAD can help you:

  • Use Analyst/PM/Architect to help plan your product
  • Use Developer/QA to help quickly implement and verify
  • Through documents and Story files, let team members take over AI-produced work outcomes at any time

Especially in scenarios requiring frequent iteration like SaaS, internal tools, e-commerce platforms, this framework from Spec to Code has significant advantages.

3. Large Companies / Enterprise Teams: Scenarios Requiring Governance, Auditing, and Compliance

Section titled “3. Large Companies / Enterprise Teams: Scenarios Requiring Governance, Auditing, and Compliance”

In more serious enterprise environments, casually writing prompts in chat boxes is hard to pass compliance and auditing. BMAD’s advantages include:

  • All instructions are reflected through files and command lines
  • All documents and code are versioned in Git
  • Workflows and responsibility divisions are traceable

This makes system prompts no longer invisible rules, but auditable, reproducible artifacts.

BMAD vs Other Solutions

Section titled “BMAD vs Other Solutions”

From the perspective of system prompt engineering / prompt repositories, BMAD is not the only solution.

Project / FrameworkCore PositioningPrompt / System Description FormIncludes Complete Development WorkflowBest Scenarios
BMAD MethodAI-driven agile development framework + agent team collaborationAgents (Markdown persona), Workflows (YAML), Templates (document templates)✅ Full chain from requirements to QASoftware and product development, teams wanting to engineer system prompts
PromptSourcePrompt IDE and repository for NLP datasets2000+ prompts for ~170 datasets, supporting template language and visual debugging❌ More biased toward dataset tasksAcademic research, benchmarking, building NLP task prompt sets
BMAD Prompt MCPBMAD-First prompt engineering serverRaw prompt → BMAD structured prompt via MCP interface🔁 Focuses on single-task prompt structuringEngineers wanting to unify prompt specifications in tools
Prompt CommonsPrompt governance and versioning in city governance scenariosVersioned prompt repository concept with governance metadata and authorization info❌ More research and concept levelResearch and government projects needing prompt management from strategy/governance perspective

Simply put:

  • PromptSource is more biased toward development tools for different NLP datasets with different prompts
  • BMAD Prompt MCP is a supplement that makes BMAD method into a prompt engineering service
  • Prompt Commons is more like a future vision and framework for city/enterprise-level prompt governance

And BMAD Method’s uniqueness lies in:

  • It designs system prompts + roles + workflows + documents as a whole
  • Provides complete implementation paths from command line to IDE, from Web UI to Git repository
  • Has formed a large open-source ecosystem and user group on GitHub (23.6k stars, 3.4k forks)

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

If we compress this article into one sentence:

BMAD Method demonstrates a typical path to system prompt engineering: abstract roles with Agents, abstract processes with Workflows, abstract outputs with Templates, and abstract the entire collaboration history with Git.

For those running tech blogs, teaching AI, or doing daily projects, what you can learn from this repository is not just which prompt works better, but:

  • How to design structured personas for different roles
  • How to create strict mapping between prompts, documents, and code
  • How to manage the entire AI collaboration process through file structure and version control

Even if you don’t directly use all of BMAD Method’s features, you can absolutely treat it as a system prompt engineering practice textbook, following its directory structure and workflow approach to build your own LLM system prompt repository.
